title: sharp rise in young people with type 2 diabetes
story: Mr Denby said: "If you're a parent looking at your child thinking they're a bit chubby, do something about it. If you're a manufacturer of sugary, fatty food, start taking some social responsibility for the foods you're producing. If you're a fast-food network, start paying some way towards the effects of the foods that you serve."If you're a government, start putting your money where your mouth is. We see an NHS that is on its knees right now and we're already preparing the next generation," he added."Each and every one of those children is going to require thousands and thousands of pounds of healthcare over the next 50, 60 years. We can't afford to let this go on any longer."The Local Government Association, which represents 370 councils in England and Wales, called for more help for obese children and ethnic minorities, as almost half of those treated in 2016-17 were black or Asian."Cutting their public health funding is short-sighted and undermines any attempt to help our children live healthy and fulfilling lives," she said.

title: postcards lost london pictures show
story: Postcards from lost London: Pictures show the tough spirit and simpler lives of a long gone East EndThe black and white images give a glimpse back into a very different east London full of barrow boys and pearly kings a long time before the hipsters.Share&nbspByMirror14:53, 18 AUG 2018Updated14:57, 18 AUG 2018NewsThere was deprivation and the bombs of the Blitz, families struggling to survive in tough conditions and few of the comforts of modern life. But these fascinating pictures from The Mirror's archive also reveal the simple pleasures and thriving community spirit of London's East End during the mid 20th century. Londoners are seen at work, rest and play with the vibrancy of the area's markets and streets taking centre stage.Diets may have left a lot to be desired but there was a huge drive to look after children's teeth as dentists became more awae of the importance of oral hygience. These little ones are lined up for a tooth cleaning parade in July 1941 (Image: Mirrorpix)1 of 20Factory girls at work in East London use candle powered search lights for lighting, April 1947 (Image: Mirrorpix)2 of 20A little girl – dressed as a pearly princess – carries a big basket of fruit to a harvest festival service in October 1973 (Image: Mirrorpix)3 of 20A traditional street party in the East End on May 3, 1935 to celebrate King George V's silver jubilee (Image: Mirrorpix)4 of 20The first large scale air raid of World War Two hit the East End in 1940. Neighbouring families looked after each other, making do and sharing humble meals with those most in need. (Image: Mirrorpix)5 of 20Pearly queens on parade. The tradition began in the 19th century with first Pearly King Henry Croft. He devised the distinctive suit and went out to raise money for charity (Image: Mirrorpix)6 of 20Fish porters at Billingsgate Market wear special flat-topped bowler hats with turned up brims, allowing them to carry big boxes of wet fish. The brims catch the drips (Image: Mirrorpix)7 of 20The East End became a melting pot of nationalities and cultures. It was around the 1880s when London's first Chinatown was established around Limehouse, where the sailors had returned to get away from their cramped shared lodging. Restaurants like this one, in 1946, became more common, and a few streets in the East End acquired Chinese names (Image: Mirrorpix)8 of 20Girls on a lunch break from a printing works are seen skipping in the street in 1953 (Image: Mirrorpix)9 of 20There may not have been much money circulating, but there was a real sense of community in the East End's pubs and clubs. A cabaret singer entertains the punters on a Saturday night in July, 1963 (Image: Mirrorpix)10 of 20The war time 'Blitz spirit' – pulling together in times of need – was nowhere more evident than in the East End. Here locals dig a trench for a communal air raid shelter in their back gardens on the day Hitler invaded Poland in September 1939 (Image: Mirrorpix)11 of 20The pet market in Bethnal Green in May 1946. People came to exchange or sell birds and animals (Image: Mirrorpix)12 of 20Children dressed in patriotic red, white and blue costumes wave flags as the Queen visits East London in June 1953 (Image: Mirrorpix)13 of 20Young girls play with their dolls and toy prams on the corner of Peace Street, formerly Artillery Street, in Bethnal Green, July 1939 (Image: Mirrorpix)14 of 20Barrow markets were a staple of East End life and the goods on sale including fabric and clothing as well as groceries (Image: Mirrorpix)15 of 20A view of the famous Petticoat Lane Market, selling clothes in 1960 (Image: Mirrorpix)16 of 20King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, visit the East End during World War Two (Image: Mirrorpix)17 of 20A busker winds up the barrel organ outside Hogarth Houses in Whitechapel, 1947 (Image: Mirrorpix)18 of 20'Back yard small holders' traded rabbits, chicks and hens for spring restocking (Image: Mirrorpix)19 of 20Every Sunday more than 3,000 locals gather on the grassy wasteland of Hackney Marshes to play football – a tradition that still continues today (Image: Mirrorpix)20 of 20More OnThe BlitzRoyal Family

title: aretha franklin showed whole world
story: NewsopinionAretha Franklin showed the whole world how it felt to be alive - and she always willFleet Street Fox whacks the volume up on the Queen of all our soulsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:54, 17 AUG 2018Updated13:07, 17 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen someone famous dies, it is usual for writers to sum up their lives in an obituary that describes their wins and losses. But I'm not going to tell you about Aretha Franklin's failings. They don't matter to a single one of us, and they don't matter any more to those closest to her. Aretha reached. That's the only word I can find to describe how her life panned out, what she achieved and what she meant. She lost her mother at 10, was pregnant by a school friend at 11, a mother at 12 and again at 15, daughter to a perverted superstar preacher who ran drug-and-sex orgies, and wife to a pimp who beat her. Singer Sam Cooke, a friend of her father's, is thought to have had sex with a 12-year-old Aretha when he was 23. Etta James, who died six years ago, was in the same congregation and said: I can understand Aretha not wanting to talk about that . . . Who wants to admit that you’re praising the Lord at the 8 p.m. service and servicing some drop-dead gorgeous hunk of a singer an hour later? Today, it's called child abuse. It's abandonment, vulnerable girls, predatory men, the most troubled and turbulent background it's possible to imagine. Yet through it Aretha reached - in the period after her mother died, she learned to play the piano by ear.  She went on the gospel circuit with her father, had her first two children and signed her first record deal. She almost signed to Tamla's motown label, which worked wonders for Diana Ross but would have buried Aretha's talent. She did better at Columbia, but in 1966 signed to the soul label Atlantic and hit the heights.  In February 1967 she released first single I Never Loved A Man. The B-side was Do Right Woman, Do Right Man. The B-side. In April she released her version of Otis Redding's Respect and in the space of just 3 months she was a megastar.  She did all that by the time she was 25, and with two children. She did it with a crappy childhood, sexual exploitation, and at a time when women and black women in particular were segregated, sidelined, and dehumanised. She did it because she reached back into her life, found the love and the pain, and hauled it up like Jonah wrestling his whale. Listen to her quiet, sad, dignified request for men to treat her kindly, and ask yourself who else could perform the same feat.  Aretha became a star for the same reason as Elvis Presley - she reached across the race divide. But while Elvis made black music acceptable by being a sexy white boy, Aretha showed that black and white both hurt the same. There's not a woman on the planet who doesn't want a Do Right Man, and after listening to that song, no man who doesn't want to do better. She sold 75million records to people who were not born in a wooden shack, weren't raised by perverts, had no interest in Baptist gospel and who nevertheless felt at one with her. When I was a teenager, she whispered in my ear about unrequited love. When I was a woman, she and I belted out songs about freedom and joy. When I fell in love we sang of our sweet, sweet baby, and when I was heartbroken, she raged with me about The House That Jack Built. And she winked at me and nodded when I changed our lyrics to demand he never came back. She was us. They were all our songs. And if she reached through it all, then we knew we could find the strength to do the same.  There is a moment in every one of her songs where you think she's given it all she can. Then she takes a breath, reaches, and finds some more. I don't know whether it's her diaphragm, her voice, or just plain magic but it elevates whoever hears it. Douglas Adams described Mark Knopfler as a man capable of making his guitar hoot and sing like angels on a Saturday night said there was a moment in every Dire Straits song where it is possible to fly. Well, Aretha sings like the angels' jaded, yet hopeful barmaid, and there is a point in every song where she lifts the weight of the world from everyone's shoulders. Her loved ones said she never sought help for her demons, never truly dealt with her drinking, gorging, and trips to mental clinics. Instead she went on stage. Perhaps if she had the help she deserved she would not have helped the rest of us realise we were not alone. She kept back the careers of her sisters, raged at friends, threw strops that would have embarrassed Henry VIII, but I don't care that she must have been hell to live with. With her, the rest of us had heaven on Earth.  She played piano like it was a percussion instrument. She arranged many of her own songs, and had the same natural talent for music that the rest of us do for breathing. But there's one story that tells you more about her than anything else.  In 1998 she was at the Grammys to perform her Blues Brothers version of Think, with John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. Her friend Luciano Pavarotti was due to perform Nessun Dorma, and despite rehearsing it perfectly he called in 30 minutes after the show began to say he had a cold and could no longer sing.  Aretha was asked to fill the gap, perhaps do one of her signature tracks. She asked instead to hear Pavarotti's rehearsal. Producer Ken Ehrlich said: In those days we had a boombox with a cassette. And I brought it to her and played it for her. When she heard it, she said, ‘Yeah, I can do this'. She went out on stage, for a live, worldwide broadcast, with an orchestra she'd not practised with, a choir she didn't know and a nervous conductor, and sang, in Italian, one of the most iconic and powerful songs in the world. One minute in, she reaches. Then reaches again, and again, and you're wowed, and somehow she reaches twice more and hits the final high note. Those final words, translated, are: At dawn, I will win. I will win, I will win!  At 16 Aretha had toured with Martin Luther King, and 10 years later sang at his funeral. She was rightly honoured and lauded throughout her later life, in 1987 she became the first woman inducted into the Rock'n'Roll Hall of Fame, and she even had an asteroid named after her. She's been called the greatest singer of all time, the voice of the civil rights movement, and much else besides. She was a spendthrift, a diva, and had a mink coat that she loved so much it used to have its own seat. Through it all, she remained an insecure little girl who thought she wasn't good enough. Still she reached for something more. More food, more drink, more men, more, more, more than this. And that's where her magic lay - the ability to show hope amid pain, to see potential in a poverty of experience. That is, after all, the thing that makes us human. We can rise, and when her voice soars it makes you feel that you have, and you can. If that's not soul, I don't know what is. In 2015 at a ceremony honouring songwriter Carol King, Aretha performed Natural Woman. She thumped those piano keys like they were in trouble, her voice hit the song at full speed, and Barack Obama wept 20 seconds after she'd opened her mouth. Halfway through, she stands up and reaches for a high note as the auditorium gives her a standing ovation. She throws that mink coat to the floor, and finds more. She goes on, and up, and up, and there's nothing the audience can do but clap harder. She was a natural woman. She made us feel what it was like to be her, and to be us, and to be human. She showed us what soul was, and she'll never stop because that voice will never be silent. My daughter will grow up with Aretha in her ears, feeling that they two alone share a secret. You make us feel, Aretha. You always will.

title: asda going sell vegan cheeseboard
story: NewsAsda is going to sell a vegan cheeseboard this ChristmasPeople who have ditched the dairy won't miss out on Christmas cheese this yearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer12:05, 18 AUG 2018NewsIt looks like a pretty good imitation of real cheese (Image: Asda)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEating way too much cheese on crackers is undeniably one of the best things about Christmas.  Now vegans won't have to miss out on the fun, as Asda is going to sell a non-dairy cheeseboard when the festive season rolls round.  The board has three different types of plant-based cheese: a traditional cheddar style vegan cheese, a garlic and chive cheddar and a Wensleydale and cranberry alternative. The cheeseboard costs &pound5, which is a bit of a bargain to be honest. However, it won't be on sale until 22 November, when the cheeseboard season really gets going.   It's not the first festive vegan offering from Asda. Last year, vegan mince pies were introduced , with the chain predicting it would sell a whopping 18 million of them.   Veganism has grown enormously in the UK. According to a survey conducted in April, 3.5 million Brits now eat a vegan diet - that's seven per cent of the population who are shunning animal products.   There are all kinds of vegan cheese out there these days, like cashew nut milk Camembert and plant-based blue.   Back in May, ASDA’s product development manager James Waters stated in a press release : We know how big the free from and vegan markets have become and understand that there is a demand for more free from and vegan products”.

title: driving instructor reveals how ex
story: NewsDriving instructor reveals how ex-pupil threatened to torture and kill him with knife – but escaped jailBob Coughtrey was forced to move house and install CCTV after the campaign by Donna Hartley, who was given a suspended sentenceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Sharpe21:15, 18 AUG 2018NewsDriving instructor Bob Coughtrey says he lives in fear (Image: John Gladwin)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driving instructor being stalked by an ex-pupil who has threatened to torture and kill him is furious that she is still not behind bars. Bob Coughtrey helped obsessed Donna Hartley through her test in six weeks. She then started a terrifying campaign.  He has been forced to move house and install CCTV . And he has counselling over fears she will track him down again.  Hartley, 29, got a suspended sentence last August after bombarding Bob with texts and turning up at his home. Within 12 months, she was convicted again after threatening to kill him – but got another suspended sentence. Bob, from Lincolnshire, said: “I’m always on edge in public, looking for a safe place and quick exit. I want to feel safe.  “What will it take for Donna to be jailed? She made my life hell and showed no regard for the first sentence. It makes a farce of the whole justice system.” He is backing the Sunday People’s campaign for a national stalkers register, adding: “I will do all I can for stalking to be taken more seriously.” Bob’s ordeal began after Hartley passed her test in June 2017 and messaged him saying she wished she had failed so they could spend more time together. “I didn’t reply but she sent loads of messages, some of which threatened self-harm,” he said.  Bob called the police , who went to check she was OK – and he was asked to call and get Hartley to let them in. He said: “I reluctantly agreed. Engaging with her was what I wanted to avoid.”  Hartley kept texting, calling and visiting his Lancashire home. She asked to meet and hug him. One text read: “I don’t want to hurt you but you can hurt me.”  She was arrested in August 2017 after turning up at his home and threatening suicide. She admitted stalking at Blackpool magistrates court and got an indefinite restraining order, plus eight weeks’ jail, suspended for 18 months, and 20 days’ rehabilitation. Bob thought the ordeal was over – until police contacted him in June. He said: “Donna told her psychiatrist she wanted to hold me hostage, torture me with a knife and kill me. I went stone cold.” As she re-offended within her suspended term, Bob assumed Hartley would be jailed or sectioned by Blackpool magistrates last month. But she got 16 weeks’ jail, suspended for two years. “I couldn’t believe it,” said Bob. “While she walks free, I don’t feel safe. The law has failed to protect me.”

title: family 11 split up across
story: NewsFamily-of-11 split up across three flats 100 miles from home because council can't find house big enoughSimone and Ansar Hussain, from Birmingham, were put up in hotels for two months before being moved into apartmentsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAshley Preece21:02, 18 AUG 2018NewsSimone and Ansar Hussain with six of their children (Image: BristolLive)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A family-of-11 have been split up across three apartment blocks 100 miles from their home town because their local council can't find a house big enough for all of them.  The Hussain family, from Birmingham, has been cooped up in hotels or flats as far away as Burton-upon-Trent and Bristol for 65 days. They are currently living in three flats in Bristol city centre as they wait for a home that can accommodate mum Simone, dad Ansar and their nine children aged between 17 months and 19 years.  The family told Birmingham Live they were illegally evicted from their privately-rented flat and they are nearing their breaking point.   Simone, 39, said: “I’m crying almost all the time now. She added: “We’ve got our nine kids with us which is hard and my 17-month-old is struggling to sleep. The other children are aged four, six, eight, 11, 12, 13, 15 and 19. Simone said: I’ve got a 21-year-old daughter back home too in Coleshill who I haven’t seen since this all started in June and that upsets me.”  She said the family were forced out of their home in Great Barr due to severe leaking and electrical faults. Birmingham City Council said they accepted their application after the family were illegally evicted from their privately-rented flat. They confirmed the family are on the housing register at the highest priority banding, but there are very few six-bedroom properties available After moving out of their rented house on June 13, the Hussains were sent to a Travelodge in Burton as their three-bed property was deemed unsafe to live in.  Twenty-eight days followed as the parents continued with the school run in Great Barr, continually going back and forth in what would have been a gruelling 42-mile trip. The family’s month-long stay ended in Burton and they were sent packing 30 minutes away to another Travelodge - this time in Rugeley. Simone, who receives &pound430-a-week in child tax credit, said: “Travelodges were horrible. You don’t have a kitchen so we couldn’t cook. “Eating out is extortionate. I kept having to borrow and borrow money - not only that but we were just stuck in a room all day and we still are.  “The kids are away from their friends all of the time. It’s just depressing and not fair on them.” After another 28-day stay at a Travelodge, the Hussains were moved on again and they were chauffeured 120 miles away to apartments in the middle of Bristol city centre, where they’re currently residing. Simone added: “The council paid for our taxis. They sent us three black cabs and the meter at the end was &pound208 - that’s 600 quid in black cabs alone. “The apartments down here are better because I can cook now and get some shopping in and stuff but, as a family, we’re spread across three apartments. It’s far from ideal.  “I think it’s about &pound150-a-night to stay here because my mum was going to come down. It’s scary. “I feel my kids are missing out on stuff, too. There’s not a lot to do - there’s no parks close by and we’re spending a fortune on petrol and parking. “We’re sweating now as well because the new school year is around the corner and I’ve got to get school uniforms. How am I meant to do that?” The Hussains were hopeful they’d return to Birmingham by August 28 but, according to the family, have now been told it is looking like September 25 instead.

title: meghan markle reveals four words
story: NewsMeghan Markle reveals the four words dad Thomas said that 'will stay with her forever'The now Duchess of Sussex has also told of the heartwarming Christmas gift her father gave her as a child - and the only time she ever saw him so enraged it made his 'eyes pop'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks18:30, 18 AUG 2018Updated19:07, 18 AUG 2018NewsThomas was Meghan's biggest supporterGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Meghan Markle and her 74-year-old father's volatile relationship has taken another battering after he likened the Royal Family to a cult last night.   The close and unrequited bond the pair once had now appears to be in tatters as Thomas Markle and Meghan's half-sister Samantha take it in turns to make public digs at Meghan, her husband Prince Harry and the Royal Family .  Meghan, however, has kept a dignified silence - and reportedly not spoken to her father since her wedding almost three months ago. But in a fresh outburst yesterday Mr Markle said of the Royal Family: “They are cult-like —– like Scientology — because they are secretive.  They close the door, pull the shades down and put their fingers in their ears so they don’t have to hear.  However before the now Duchess of Sussex, 37, met Harry she lovingly described Mr Markle as the most hardworking father you can imagine.  She laid bare her love for the man who always believed she would be a success and who made sacrifices so she could fulfill her dream of becoming an actress. She also told of the heartwarming Christmas gift her father gave her as a child, which she pictured him getting glares for from mums. And the only time she ever saw him so enraged it made his 'eyes pop'. Meghan has also revealed the four words her father told her that will stay with her forever: “Draw your own box.” It was after Meghan came home one day from school upset.  Recalling the incident, she says she had to fill out a census form before an English exam and tick whether she was white, black, Hispanic or Asian. Being biracial - with a Caucasian father and a African American mother - she didn't know which box she fitted into, so out of confusion and sadness she left it blank. When she told her father what happened she admits she had never seen him angry before, but she could see the blotchiness of his skin crawling from pink to red. It made the green of his eyes pop and his brow was weighted at the thought of his daughter being prey to ignorance, she said. And in one of those parenting moments that no guidebook could ever prep you for, my dad said words that will stay with me forever: 'Draw your own box.'    He wanted me to see beyond that census placed in front of me. He wanted me to find my own truth. Meghan has made no secret of struggling with her identity growing up, even saying her 20s were brutal.  She recalls being at home in LA on a college break when her mother, Doria Ragland , was called the ‘N’ word.  She said: We were leaving a concert and she wasn’t pulling out of a parking space quickly enough for another driver. My skin rushed with heat as I looked to my mom. Her eyes welling with hateful tears, I could only breathe out a whisper of words, so hushed they were barely audible: ‘It’s OK, Mommy.’ I was trying to temper the rage-filled air permeating our small silver Volvo. We drove home in deafening silence, her chocolate knuckles pale from gripping the wheel so tightly.  Meanwhile, so conscious his young daughter was wrestling with who she was as a person, Mr Markle one Christmas took apart two Barbie boxed sets, which came as a white Barbie family or a black one, to make a custom one for Meghan. When I was about seven, I had been fawning over a boxed set of Barbie dolls, she said. It was called The Heart Family and included a mom doll, a dad doll, and two children. This perfect nuclear family was only sold in sets of white dolls or black dolls. I don’t remember coveting one over the other, I just wanted one. On Christmas morning, swathed in glitter-flecked wrapping paper, there I found my Heart Family: a black mom doll, a white dad doll, and a child in each color. My dad had taken the sets apart and customized my family. Meghan Markle's rise to royalty in pictures - from starry-eyed child to Duchess of Sussex

They didn’t accept anyone else so they couldn’t make an exception for me.” Michael was speaking after a barrage of insults and interviews directed at the royals by other members of his family.  Meghan’s dad has revealed intimate details of conversations with Prince Harry, 33, and even confessed how he lied to the Duke of Sussex about faking pictures with a British paparazzi. It turned out they were all staged. Now Thomas feels he has been dumped by his daughter. For years he worked long hours as a Hollywood lighting technician to help Meghan through private school and realise her dream of becoming an actress. With Meghan’s half-sister Samantha boasting of an upcoming salacious biography titled In The Shadows Of The Duchess, Michael insists he is the only member of the Markle family who has shown any loyalty.  He revealed how his connections helped secure Meghan a prestigious internship at the American embassy in Buenos Aires, Argentina, when she was 20. Other Markle relatives weighed in with their tuppence worth, causing huge embarrassment before and after the big day. And amid the fake pics furore, Thomas pulled out of the ceremony suffering heart problems with just days to go.  The whole, sorry saga has left Meghan even more reliant on mum Doria, 61, who has been her rock throughout. Michael has previously told how he thought his niece’s attitude towards her family was “uncalled for”. He said before the wedding: “I don’t understand why she has been so &shyindifferent towards me. It’s uncalled for. I helped her out and I didn’t ask for anything in return.” Despite the disappointment at missing out on the big day, a neighbour at the trailer park retirement village told how Michael was delighed about the wedding. After moving in to his &pound78,000 home he told everyone about his niece.  The source said: “He’s very proud of Meghan. When he moved in he asked everyone if they knew who she was and that she was marrying Prince Harry.” Meghan is expected to move her mum from the US to London as she embarks on the next stage of her marriage. A royal insider said: “The trip is likely to be a welcome distraction for everyone, but especially for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex. “Royal aides have been increasingly under pressure to find a way out of this crisis as the Markle family show no signs of keeping quiet. “So far Meghan and Harry have decided to stay quiet but something will have to give sooner rather than later.” Earlier this month it was revealed how royal advisers have held a series of crisis summits on how to stop Thomas Markle from heaping further distress on his daughter.  At least three meetings have taken place between Meghan and Harry’s senior team and other royal advisers to find a solution. Three options have been laid out to Meghan to try to resolve the public breakdown in relations with her dad. story: NewsPrincess Charlotte could nab the fanciest royal title of all - but she'll have to wait for itOnce Prince William becomes the King of England, little Charlotte will inherit a very special royal titleShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer15:30, 18 AUG 2018Updated15:58, 18 AUG 2018NewsPrincess Charlotte could get an enviably fancy title (Image: Getty Images Europe)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email As any royal fan will know, it's pretty much inevitable that Prince William will be crowned King at some point in the future.   Once that happens, there will be some serious shake ups in the Royal Family . William will be the King of England, Kate will become Queen and Prince George will be next in line to the throne.   Princess Charlotte will still be a princess. But there's another very special title she will inherit when King Will is on the throne.  Her future title is actually even fancier than Her Royal Highness's name already: Princess Royal.  However, the title is not up for grabs just yet as it already belongs to someone else. Traditionally, Princess Royal is bestowed to the eldest daughter of the monarch. So it's currently held by Charlotte's great aunt and the Queen's sis, Princess Anne - who is 68. If she passes away, the title may be transferred to Princess Charlotte, but it doesn't happen automatically and is up to Prince William.  Royal expert and author of Prince Harry : The Inside Story, Duncan Larcombe told Town and Country , The title of Princess Royal is traditionally bestowed on the eldest daughter of the monarch.  Princess Anne had to wait until 1987 before her mother the queen bestowed the title of Princess Royal on her, even though the title had been vacant since 1965.

story: NewsTeen becomes first model with Down’s syndrome to win global beauty pageantEXCLUSIVE: Kate Grant, 19, was overwhelmed with shock when she was picked out from 40 other candidates to be crowned Teen Ultimate Beauty Of The WorldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKim Willis20:36, 18 AUG 2018Updated20:38, 18 AUG 2018NewsKate Grant had been invited to enter as the representative for her native Northern IrelandGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeenager Kate Grant has &shybecome the first model with Down’s syndrome to win an &shyinternational beauty pageant. Kate, 19, was overwhelmed with shock when she was picked out from 40 other candidates to be crowned Teen Ultimate Beauty Of The World. The pageant is held to celebrate &shydiversity and people who are “beautiful inside and out” – and supports the Make-A-Wish Foundation, a charity which makes dreams come true for poorly children. Kate had dabbled with modelling before the two-day event and &shyentered it only for experience. And she admitted it was a massive surprise when she heard her name read out as the winner. She said: “I was in shock. My family were all in the audience, &shycrying and cheering. “My dream has come true. And that dream is to get a chance to inspire young people who have Down’s &shysyndrome and other special needs to believe in themselves.”  Kate had been invited to enter as the representative for her native Northern Ireland by the pageant’s director, Taylor-Rae Hamilton. Taylor-Rae was one of hundreds of people touched by a message Kate’s mum Deirdre had posted on Facebook asking for support in her attempts to become a successful model. Kate travelled just 25 miles from her home in Cookstown, Co Tyrone, to the contest venue in Portadown, where other candidates had assembled after flying in from all around the world to represent their nations.  The pageant has three categories for kids, teens and over-20s and is open to anyone regardless of weight, height or marital status. The contest began with an interview by a panel of judges. Kate’s mum was not allowed in the room with her, but could hear her making the judges laugh. Deirdre said: “I knew she’d charm them but what made me most proud was how Kate looked after other candidates, &shyencouraging and supporting them.” That evening, candidates of all ages mingled at a “get to you know you” party with a tropical beach theme. Day Two was catwalk day. The first round was casual, so Kate wore jeans and a white T-shirt. The second round was called Time to Shine, which Kate said “meant hair curled, make-up applied and a sparkling, turquoise sequined dress, channelling my inner Little Mermaid”.  For the formal round, Kate wore a black and white cocktail dress with a side split. She said: “I sashayed down the catwalk giving it all my sass. I just wanted to have fun and truly expected someone else’s name to be called as the winner. “Now I’ll be attending photoshoots throughout the year and will be a judge and mentor at next year’s final. “Most importantly I’ll be involved in an appeal where we’ll deliver hundreds of toys to the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. I want to give poorly children a moment of sunshine.” Kate has previously walked the catwalk at Belfast Fashion Week and taken part in campaigns for boutiques in her home town.Today she will be wearing her sash and crown again at the start of the Red Dress Run in aid of the Chest, Heart and Stroke Foundation in Lurgan, Co Armagh.  But the road to success has not been easy. When she was born doctors told her parents Deirdre and John to &shyprepare for the worst and hope for the best. Deirdre said: “After two sons, John and I were thrilled to be expecting a girl. “When Kate was born it was confirmed she had Down’s syndrome within hours. “The doctor painted a bleak future. He said she wouldn’t learn to read, her speech would be limited and she’d never hold full conversations. I thought of him as she made her acceptance speech up on the stage at the pageant, describing her hopes for an inclusive society, one where people like her are treated as equals.” Deirdre and John agreed to raise Kate no differently to their sons Patrick and Michael, then 11 and two. Two years later younger sister Ella joined the family. Deirdre said: “When she announced at 13 she wanted to be a model we didn’t discredit the idea just because she had Down’s syndrome.” Kate discovered a passion for make-up, clothes and fashion and never wavered in her ambition. But she &shystruggled to get any gigs. Her mum emailed agencies with photos but was &shytold there was no work.

story: NewsUK's youngest Lotto winner Callie Rogers admits biggest regret is having no money left to support disabled sonCallie Rogers, 31, scooped £1.8m in 2003 but say she wishes she had saved some of her winnings for her six-year-old boy BlakeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth08:16, 18 AUG 2018Updated09:47, 18 AUG 2018NewsCallie Roger's biggest regret is having no money left to care for disabled son (Image: callierogers86/Instagram)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email One of the UK's youngest lottery winners has spoken of her regret at not saving money to support her disabled son.   Callie Rogers was only 16 when she scooped the &pound1.8million prize in 2003.  Much of her fortune went on &pound18,000 for boob jobs, &pound250,000 on cocaine, another &pound300,000 on clothes and she gave away &pound500,000 to friends and family. However, Mrs Rogers says she wishes that she had saved some of her winnings for her son Blake who has cerebral palsy. The six-year-old cannot walk, talk or swallow unaided.  She told the MailOnline : I was never one for designer clothes or flash cars.  But it’s my one big regret is that the money isn’t here for Blake.  He loves sensory stimulation. Within weeks she met Nicky Lawson, father of her two eldest children, and had moved out to be with him. She quit work and splashed out on designer clothes, lavish presents for her biological parents and holidays, spending quarter of a million pounds on cocaine.  Now the single mum works as a carer, after going back to school to study social care. She stays in a &pound400-a-month house in a cul-de-sac in Workington, Cumbris and says she now does her shopping at Asda. The mum-of-three said: My kids don’t want for anything. At the end of the month there is usually enough for a few treats, but I couldn’t go out and buy a new car tomorrow. She added: If I want a holiday, I have to save.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Storm Ernesto to hit Britain TONIGHT bringing wildfire smoke from US and CanadaForecasters say the smell of the fires and small amounts of soot could be detected as 40mph winds hit the UK from about 6pm on SaturdayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop16:55, 18 AUG 2018Updated17:27, 18 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSubtropical Storm Ernesto is set to batter parts of Britain with strong winds and rain that could carry smoke from America and Californian wildfires. Forecasters say the smell of the fires and small amounts of soot could be detected as 40mph winds hit the UK from about 6pm on Saturday. The storm is currently making its way over the Atlantic and is set to lose its storm status by the time it reaches the UK. However Ernesto will still bring heavy rain and winds set to hit on Saturday and last into Sunday. The north of the country is set to be hit hardest with heavy rain and strong winds.   Where is Storm Ernesto going to hit? Ex tropical storm to batter parts of UK with wind and rain this weekend        Up to a centimetre of rain could fall in Ireland and central and southern Scotland overnight. Parts of Wales and northern England will see scattered showers with some parts getting up to 15mm of rain overnight on Saturday and into Sunday lunchtime. Northern England can also expect windy conditions on Saturday. Further south winds will be lighter, with patches of warm sunshine. On Sunday heavy rain is again expected in the north of England. To the south wind speeds will be more moderate with wind speeds of close to 20 mph although some gusts could peak at 40 mph in parts of Wales and southwestern England.    The US National Hurricane Centre reported that Ernesto had winds of 45mph as it blew in over the Azores on Friday. As the storm passed over California and Canada it picked up smoke and soot from wildfires, according to the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration. story: NewsWoman's car swallowed bonnet-first into '20ft-deep' sinkhole in grounds of Welsh castleTwo vehicles had to pull the car out of the sinkhole at Craig y Nos Castle in the upper Swansea Valley while shocked passersby watched on in amazementShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEstel Farell-Roig13:49, 18 AUG 2018Updated15:02, 18 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother thought it was a joke when she discovered her car had been swallowed by a sinkhole in the ground of a Welsh castle. The dinky white car slowly sunk into the '20ft-deep' crater while shocked passersby watched on in amazement. Luke Davies said his mum Karen didn't believe it when people told her what had happened - and she thought it was all a joke. It took two vehicles to pull the car out of the sinkhole at Craig y Nos Castle in the upper Swansea Valley.  Mr Davies said he was in Swansea when he had a call from his father telling him about what happened, reports Wales Online .   The 30-year-old said his mum - who works in the castle - had left the car in the car park in the morning and that not long before she was due to finish work at around 4pm she found out about the sinkhole. She was in shock and at first she thought it was a joke, he added. The car was upside down. A customer was in the car park when it started sinking - they saw it happen and how it gradually went down. They spoke to a member of staff but by the time my mum found out the car had sunk completely.  They believe the sinkhole may have been caused by a stream of water coming from the mountain opposite the castle, he continued, eroding the ground under the car park. Mr Davies, from Coelbren in Powys , said the manager attached a rope to his truck and to the car to stop it from going any further as, below the car, the sinkhole was 18 to 20 feet in the deepest part. He said: The pictures don't do justice to how deep it was - I didn't realise how bad it was until I saw it. We had to wait for recovery for a couple of hours and then they were concerned about causing more damage to the car while towing it out. We did consider getting a crane but we couldn't get one.

title: you cant blame one doctor
story: NewsopinionYou can't blame one doctor for an ailing NHSLast Tuesday the General Medical Council overturned its previous decision and reinstated Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba to the register so she can return to workShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAnne Diamond19:09, 18 AUG 2018NewsopinionDr Hadiza Bawa-Garba (Image: PA)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe trouble with the case of the overworked junior doctor and the little boy who died from undiagnosed sepsis is that your heart bleeds for everyone involved. Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba should never have been struck off – but who can blame the parents for wanting to prevent a similar tragedy ever happening to anyone else? As a mum myself, I have the greatest, heart-rending sympathy for the parents of six-year-old Jack Adcock, who died just 12 hours after being admitted to hospital with vomiting and diarrhoea. His life could easily have been saved, had the seriousness of his condition been spotted in time. Quite understandably, Victor and Nicky Adcock feel anger as well as grief. So when Dr Bawa-Garba was convicted of manslaughter and struck off the medical register, they vowed to celebrate with champagne at Jack’s grave.  This week, however, eight years after their little boy’s death, they were dealt an unexpected blow – and one which has left them reeling. Because last Tuesday the General Medical Council overturned its previous decision and reinstated Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba to the register so she can return to work. Indeed, they now say she should never have been struck off, and that she was “a competent and useful doctor, who can provide considerable useful future service to society.” Like the Adcocks, I was at first stunned. As Jack’s mum said this week: “How can somebody make that many mistakes, be found guilty by a jury and be able to practise again? If you walked into a hospital and saw that doctor, would you be happy for her to treat your child?” Not me, I thought. But dig a bit deeper, and it is so much more complicated than that. Terrible tragedy though it was, was it also a case of an overworked and under-supported doctor being “thrown under the bus” as the huge social media storm has suggested?

story: NewsGirl, 18, who pushed friend off 60ft bridge could face jail after being charged with reckless endangermentTaylor Smith, 18, sent pal Jordan Holgerson plunging into a river after shoving her off the bridge in Washington state, US, leaving her with multiple injuries.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop08:08, 18 AUG 2018Updated08:14, 18 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe woman who pushed her 16-year-old friend off a 60-foot bridge could be facing up to one year behind bars after being charged with one count of reckless endangerment. Taylor Smith, 18, sent pal Jordan Holgerson plunging into a river after shoving her off the bridge in Washington state, US, leaving her with multiple injuries. Prosecutors filed the charge yesterday as an officer said her actions created a substantial risk of death and resulted in serious physical injury to Jordan Holgerson. Reckless endangerment is punishable by up to a year in jail and a maximum fine of &pound3,900. Earlier, Taylor - who family recently claimed 'didn't care about what she'd done - said facing charges is scary but she will accept whatever the prosecutor gives me.  Taylor spoke out after the charge, telling ABC News: I accept the charges maturely and all I can do is hope for the best for Jordan and myself, Smith told late Friday.  Jordan, initially said she 'didn't really want' Taylor to get into trouble but earlier this week she told NBC News : I'm kind of wanting her to sit in jail and think about at least what she did.  She added: I'm in a lot of pain. In the mornings it's the worst, like it hurts to breathe. My side hurts. My shoulder hurts. I can't even get up. Jordan suffered serious injuries in the plunge, including six broken ribs, a punctured lung and air bubbles in her chest after she plunged the equivalent of three storeys into Lewis River at Moulton Falls Regional Park near Vancouver on August 7.  According to the complaint filed in Clark County district court, Jordan told authorities that Taylor was the one who pushed her and that it was unwanted. Taylor admitted to pushing her off the bridge but told authorities she did so in an attempt to help her friend overcome her fear and not to injure her. Earlier Friday Taylor said she didn't consider the repercussions beforehand, adding: She wanted to jump and she was scared and she had asked me to give her a push, and I didn't think about the consequences. I thought she would be fine. Taylor said she immediately apologised several times after the incident and even tried to visit her in the hospital but was asked to leave.  She said Jordan has since stopped speaking to her. Jordan said she had initially wanted to jump off the bridge after seeing a friend do it, but she got scared when she got to the top. She said: She was counting down but I didn’t think anything of it. And I was like, 'No, don’t count down, like, I won’t go if you count down. I’m not ready.' And then she pushed me. Jordan said she didn't feel any pain but adrenaline kicked in after she belly-flopped into the water. But Taylor claimed she never intended to hurt her friend, adding: I'm really sorry it turned out that way. I just pray that she heals and gets better.  Dramatic video footage captured Jordan falling dozens of feet from the bridge in Moulton Falls Regional Park, Yacolt. The teenager could be seen standing nervously at the edge of the structure, before her pal, later identified as Taylor, pushed her from behind. Surrounded by friends, she was reportedly heard saying no twice, before plunging into the Lewis River. She landed with a 'belly flop'.  Jordan sister, Vanessa, spoke to KOIN in Canada shortly after the incident.  I think she [the friend] tried to do it jokingly and didn't think what could have happened, Vanessa said. You don't really play around at 60 feet.
